abstract.p: Various polymer materials incorporated into the interlayer spaces of montmorillonite (MMT) has received a great dealofattention in the research field of clay-polymer nanocomposites. This is due to the dramatic enhancements in physical properties, such as thermal and mechanical properties, of such nanocomposites compared to their parent materials. Inthis paper, the thermal behavior of montmorillonite-polyaniline nanocomposites is analyzed in a wide range of temperatures (30–1000°C) by the thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and by differential scanning calorimetry (DSC). Inair, the thermal degradation of polyaniline (PANI) (chemically polymerized) starts at 255°C, whereas that in Na+-intercalated MMT-polyaniline and in Ce(IV)-intercalated MMT-polyaniline nanocomposites start at 290 and 330°C, respectively. This improvement in the thermal stability of PANI in the nanocomposites is attributed to the presence of polyaniline in the nano-scaled MMT interlayer spaces in a high aspect ratio where the MMT layers are acting as barriers protecting PANI from degradation. XRD, SEM, and FT-IR data support this conclusion. Better stability of polyaniline in Ce(IV)-intercalated MMT may be due the formation of ordered well-aligned polymer only within the inter-galleries of MMT with a high aspect ratio. In the case of Na+-MMT-polyaniline nanocomposites the polymer is present within the interlayer spaces as well as in the exfoliate form and hence lower thermal stability of polyaniline when compared to that in Ce(IV)-intercalated nanocomposites.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Nanocomposites are a new class of composites, which aremultiphase solid materials of which at least one phase is in the nanometer range, that is, between 1 and 100 nm. The structures having polymers incorporated into the solid layered materials with nano-scale repeat distances between the different phases can also be considered as nanocomposites.1 Such layered silicate/polymer (LSP) nanocomposites have attracted a great deal of interest in recent research, because of their significant improvements in physical properties, such as mechanical properties (tensile modulus and strength, flexural modulus and strength), thermal stability, flame retardancy and barrier properties2–6 over their individual parents. The electronically conducting polymers incorporated into MMT has attracted unique attention duetotheir potential technological applications in light-emitting diodes, lightweight battery electrodes, sensors, electro-optics, electromagnetic shielding materials, biochemical capacitors, fuel cell electrodes and as anticorrosive coatings.7–9 Among the conducting polymers, polyaniline (PANI) is a promising polymer due to its simple synthesis, high electrical conductivity and excellent environment stability.10 However, its poorthermal and mechanical properties restrict its commercial applications and, therefore, methods to improve such properties are of great importance.11,12 MMT-PANI nanocomposites have numerous potential applications including electrodes for rechargeable batteries,13 electrodes for energy storage devices,14,15 electromagnetic interference shielding,16–18 electronic and optical devices,19–23 smart windows14 and in light-emitting diodes.14,20,24

In the author's our recent publications, we presented different types of MMT nanocomposites with electronically conducting polymers such as polypyrrole,25,26 polyanilne,27–34 and poly(3,4-ethylene dioxythiophene)2,25 were presented. Their previous studies mainly focused on mechanical properties,33,35 conductivity,36 and electrochemical measurements34 of the clay polymer nanocomposites. In this publication, the thermal properties of MMT-PANI nanocomposites are discussed.

The MMT consists of alumina octahedral sheets sandwiched between two silicon tetrahedra40 and the final structure of 2:1 phyllosilicates is formed by alternating these three-sheet layers with a gallery (the space between two of three-sheet layers) containing water andexchangeable metal counter ions such as Na+ and Ca2+.42 The layer thickness is around 1 nm but the lateral dimensions of these layers can vary from nanometer scale to several microns depending on the type of the silicate used.39 Isomorphic substitutions of aluminum by magnesium or iron by magnesium in the octahedral sheet generate these negative charges to the clay sheets.44 The gallery regions containing Na+ and Ca2+ counterbalances the negative charge of the sheets and serve to hold the individual negatively charged clay layers together through electrostatic forces.42,43 The layers are held together by the van der Waals forces and hence the interlayer distances can vary depending on the radius of the cation present and its degree of hydration.44 This ready expandability can lead to an easy intercalation of small molecules and ions between the layers. One of the important characteristic of the 2:1phyllosilicates such as montmorillonite is their possibility to absorb some of cations and keep them in an exchangeable state. Therefore, these interlayer cations can be exchanged by treatment of inorganic cations such as Na+, Ca2+, Mg2+, H+, K+, Cu(II), NH4 +, Fe(III), Ce(IV) and also organic cations such as quaternary ammonium ions, anilinium ions and so on in an aqueous solution.45,46 The excess negative charge of layered silicates and their competence to exchange ions can be quantified by the cation exchange capacity (CEC).5,41,47 In this study, the inorganic cations present in the interlayer are exchanged with Ce(IV) in order to provide highly oxidizing environment in the MMT interlayer. Polyaniline/MMT-nanocomposites were prepared by introducing the aniline monomer into the galleries containing Ce(IV) ions and allowing to polymerize to form extended chains of PANI in the MMT interlayers. Herein, we describe the synthesis and characterization of the nanocomposites of PANI-MMT and their characterization by X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), Fourier transform Infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), and the study of thermal properties by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and by differential scanning calorimetry (DSC).

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: All chemicals used were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. Sodium montmorillonite (Na+-MMT) with a cation exchange capacity of 100 mEq per 100 g was used as inorganic host material. Aniline was distilled under reduced pressure and stored in a refrigerator (4°C) before use.

sec.title: Synthesis of Ce(IV)-MMT clay composite
sec.p: The raw clay (MMT) was suspended in distilled water (10 g of powdered clay in 500 cm3) by vigorous stirring for 72 h in oder to obtain fine MMT by separating from coarser impurities. Such fine particles of clay (MMT) have been separated from coarser impurities by passing the slurry through a sieve, centrifuging the mixture, decanting the solution layer and repeating the procedure for four times and finally air drying the residue. The dried MMT clay was then characterized by XRD, FTIR, and TG analysis.

Na+ ions in MMT was then exchanged for Ce(IV) ions by the ion-excange procedure involving the suspension of purified dry Na+-MMT clay (5 g) in a 0.5 M of Ce(SO4)2 aqueous solution (200 cm3) and stirring for 72 h. The suspension was then centrifuged and the aqueous layer was discarded. The above procedure was repeated until successive washings showed negative test for sulfate ions. The pale yellow colored Ce(IV)-MMT clay sample was then dried under ambient air for a week and ground well to obtain fine particles.

sec.title: Synthesis of PANI/Na+-MMT nanocomposite
sec.p: One g of Na+-MMT was treated with a mixture of solvents (10 cm3 water, 10 cm3 of 1.5 mol/dm3 HCl, and 20 cm3 methanol) and subsequently by adding aniline (1.10 g of aniline) to the mixture and vigorously stirring for 72 h to exchange some sodium ions by anilinium ions. Such anilinium-exchanged MMT was then treated with 25 cm3 of 0.4 mol/dm3 S2O8 2- ions for oxidative polymerization. After the polymerization, the sample was precipitated by centrifuging and the supernatant decanted. The residue was stirred with 250 cm3 of distilled water, again centrifuged and the supernatant decanted, This procedure was repeated until the supernatant is free of chloride ions (tested using AgNO3 solution). The purified composite is termed PANI/Na+-MMT, which was dried under ambient laboratory conditions and subsequently in a vacuum desiccator.

sec.title: Synthesis of PANI/Ce(III)- MMT nanocomposites
sec.p: PANI/Ce(III)-MMT nanocomposites were prepared by the intercalation of aniline monomer in the Ce(IV) MMT followed by the polymerization of aniline in the galleries.2,25,27–32 This was done first by treating 1 g of dried Ce(IV)- MMT clay with a mixture of solvents (10 cm3 water, 10 cm3 of 1.5 mol/dm3 HCl, and 20 cm3 methanol) and subsequently by adding aniline (1.10 g of aniline) to the mixture and vigorously stirring for 72 h. The resultant green colored suspension was centrifuged, supernatant decanted, again stirred with DDW, centrifuged and the process repeated until the supernatant is free of chloride. Then, the dark green PANI/Ce(III)- MMT clay was allowed to dry in the ambient laboratory environment and subsequently dried in a desiccator to remove any excess solvent trapped within the nanocomposite.

sec.title: Characterization of clay-polymer nanocomposites
sec.p: X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis. Computer controlled X-ray diffractometer (MINIFlex II, Rigaku, Japan, Cu-Kα radiation, α = 0.1540562 nm) was employed for the XRD analysis which was done at 40 kV and 30 mA settings with a scan rate of 0.1 θ/min. For this study, powered nanocomposite samples were used. The XRD measurements were recorded for as-prepared samples at room temperature as well as for samples heat-treated at 150°C for 2 h.

Scanning electron microscopic analysis. SEM images were taken with a Hitachi S-3000 N scanning electron microscope (SEM) with an accelerating voltage of 15 kV. They were taken for samples at ambient temperature as well as those samples heat-treated at 150°C for 2 h.

Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR). Infrared absorption spectra were recorded using NICOLET 6700 FTIR spectrometer with 64 accumulations at 4 cm−1 resolution. Then 1.2 mg of sample (dispersed in KBr as pellets in the mass ratio of sample: KBr = 1:100) was used to record the IR absorption spectra in the spectral range 4000–400 cm−1 with a resolution of 4 cm−1.

Thermogravimetric (TG) and differential scanning calorimetric (DSC) analysis Thermo–gravimetric anddifferential scanning calorimetric analyses of clay-polymer nanocomposite samples were carried out using SCINCO STA N-1500 thermogravimetric analyzer. Then 30 mg of the sample was heated through the temperature range of 25–1000°C at a rate of 5 C min−1 and the respective spectra were collected.

sec.title: X-ray diffraction studies
sec.p:
The intercalation of cerium ions and PANI in to the Na+-MMT layers have been observed by XRD patterns which give their interlayer spacing (d-spacing) values. XRD pattern of sodium montmorillonite (Figure 1(a)) shows peak at about 2θ = 7.20° with basal spacing of 1.22 nm. XRD pattern of cerium intercalated montmorillonite (shown in Figure 1(b)) exposed a shift in the peak position (2θ changed from 7.20° to 6.64°), which means the basal spacing increases due to cerium ion intercalation. The intercalation of Ce(IV) ion into the clay galleries (d-spacing) facilitate through the ion exchange reaction between Na+-clay and the Cerium(IV) ions in the aqueous medium, which has expanded the d-spacing from 1.22 to 1.32 nm and confirm the modification of the clay particles with Ce(IV).48 However, d-spacing value is decreased after the heat treatment at 150°C for about 2 h for both the Na+-MMT and Ce(IV) MMT and this change is due to the removal of water layers around these ions present within the interlayers of MMT. The d-spacing of the materials is calculated from the angular position 2θ of the observed peaks using the Bragg equation, d = λ/2sinθ, where λ is the X-ray wavelength and θ is the Bragg angle. The basal spacing (d) values of Na+-MMT and Ce(IV)- MMT are shown in Table 1. XRD pattern of PANI clay nanocomposites is shownin Figure 2(c). The peak positions of the pristine Na+-MMT between 2θ = 7° –8° has been shifted towards lower angles for both the nanocomposites indicating the increase in the d-spacings.48 Table 1.

As shown in XRD pattern of the PANI clay nanocomposites, the basal spacing of the Ce(IV)-MMT is further expanded due to the intercalation of the polyaniline (PANI) by spontaneous polymerization of aniline monomer within the clay interlayers. This oxidative polymerization of aniline is facilitated by reducing Ce(IV) in to Ce(III) within the clay layers. Upon the intercalation of Ce(IV) ion, the interlayer spacing is expanded from 1.22 to 1.32 nm and in the case of the intercalation of PANI, the interlayer expansion is up to 1.48 nm. Thus, the 0.52 nm expansion in the interlayer spacing of MMT, which has been observed in this study, indicates the insertion of cerium ions as well asPANI chains between the silicate layers. However, d -spacing value of nanocomposites at 25 and 150°C are not significantly changed indicating that the absence of water layers around PANI or Ce(III) in the nanocomposite.2 The XRD results of the PANI clay nanocomposites are summarized in Table 1. The interlayer spacing (Δd) of the modified MMT was calculated bysubtracting the three-sheet layer (aluminum octahedral sheet sandwiched between two silicon tetrahedra) value of the pristine Na+-MMT45 and is also comparable to the data reported by other groups.46,49

sec.title: Scanning electron microscopy
sec.p:
Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was used to examine the morphology of the clay polymer nanocomposite. Depicted in Figure 3(a) and (b) are the SEM images of pristine montmorillonite and Ce(IV)-MMT, respectively. Both these MMTs have a slatted texture reflecting its layered structure.49 These, irregular plate-like MMT particles are in micrometer range in two dimensions, that is, length and width. As shown in the SEM image, original structure of MMT has changed with the intercalation of PANI (Figure 3(c)). These figures clearly show that the slatted texture of MMT is covered with spherical PANI particles49 and reveal remarkable morphological differences between the pristine MMT clay and the PANI/Ce(III)- MMT nanocomposite. sec.title: TGA and DSC studies
sec.p:
The DSC and TGA thermograms for Ce(IV) ion intercalated MMT, PANI and Nanocomposites are shown in Figures 4 and 5, respectively. In general, montmorillonite shows three weight-loss process and PANI showstwo weight-loss process,48 whereas, nanocomposites show four weight-loss process. The first weight-loss (endotherm) corresponds to the loss of water from the interlayer galleries of Ce(IV) ion intercalated MMT and nanocomposites.9 DSC thermogram of PANI has also shown endotherm at around 100°C and it is due to the loss of water (dehydration). Final endotherms are attributed to the dehydroxylation of silicate structure of Ce(IV)-MMT and clay polymer nanocomposites. Generally, final weight-loss appears in the temperature range of 650–900°C for both the montmorillonite and the nanocomposites.50 The DSC thermograms for nanocomposites show a strong exotherm (condensation, crystallization) corresponding to the decomposition of PANI bonded to the MMT clay. The decomposition of PANI bonded to MMT clay occurs in the higher temperature range from 330 to 510°C for PANI/Ce(III)-MMT nanocomposite whereas for PANI/Na+-MMT nanocomposites which exists in the temperature range 290–500°C. The bare PANI shows an exotherm in the temperature range of 255–475°C due to its decomposition. The exothermic effect of nanocomposites has significantly shifted to a higher temperature when compared to that of the bare PANI. Such improvement could be due to the thermal protection provided by the nanoscaled MMT layers whose high aspect ratio acting as barriers preventing the thermal degradation of PANI.14 Figure 4.
DSC curves for PANI/Ce(III)-MMT, Ce(IV)-MMT and PANI, where MMT = montmorillonite and PANI = polyaniline. Figure 5.
TGA curves for PANI/Ce(III)-MMT, Ce(IV)-MMT and PANI, where MMT = montmorillonite and PANI = polyaniline.

Weight-loss during the exotherm reveals the amount of polymer that has intercalated into the MMT layers (Table 2). Surprisingly, the weight-loss is almost the same for both the nanocomposites, PANI/Na+-MMT and PANI/Ce(III)-MMT. This result suggests that intercalated cerium ion also effectively polymerize aniline monomer in the same way as the external oxidant (S2O8 2- ions) introduced does in the PANI-Na+-MMT synthesis. As recorded in TGA, weight-loss due to the dehydration of nanocomposites is significantly different from that of cerium ion intercalated MMT (Table 3). Such behavior could be due to the intercalation of PANI into MMT layers with concomitant removal of water due to PANI intercalation. The weight loss around 100°C corresponds to the elimination of water2 in PANI/Ce(III)-MMT and accounted for up to 10% of the original mass whereas in Ce(IV)-MMT it is about 17%. Two consecutive endotherms, appearing in the range 600–900°C, shown in the DSC thermograms of the nanocomposites,2,50 correspond to the release of structural water from the decomposition of bonded hydroxyl groups (dehydroxylation).2 Table 3.

Above results conclude that the increase in decomposition temperature of PANI may be due to the the shielding effect of the cerium intercalted MMT layers.This could be due to the formation of well-ordered pattern of PANI chains within the interlayers of cerium intercalated MMT. Such clay polymer nanocomposites could be obtained due to the polymerization of aniline monomer by cerium ions within the MMT gallery. Apart from that higher amount of PANI could be intercalated into Ce(IV)-MMT galleries due to this in-situ polymerization. However, thermal stability of PANI/Na+-MMT is different from PANI/Ce(III)-MMT due to the lesser amount of PANI intercalation into Na+-MMT layers

and the possible presence of unintercalated PANI chains. These free PANI chains would decompose at lower temperatures than those present within the interlayers. This may explain the better thermal stability of PANI/Ce(III)-MMT compared to PANI/Na+-MMT.

sec.title: FTIR studies
sec.p:
FT-IR measurements for the PANI clay nanocomposites were performed at four different temperatures toinvestigate the structural changes of clay-polymer nanocomposites with the temperatures. Figure 6 shows FTIR spectra of PANI/Ce(III)-MMT at four different temperatures. Characteristic bands corresponding to pure PANI emeraldine salt form are observed (Figure 6(a)) in PANI/Ce(III)-MMT, which confirms the existence of PANI in the emeraldine salt form (PANI-ES) in the nanocomposites. However, we have found slight difference in the characteristic bands of the pure PANI-ES and in PANI clay nanocomposites. Such deviation could be due to the interactions between the polymer chains and MMT clay and the data are given in the Table 4. All the characteristic peaks attributed to PANI have disappeared from the FTIR spectra of heat-treated (at high temperatures above 600°C) nanocomposites due to the decomposition of polyaniline above 600°C. sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: PANI/Ce(III)-MMT has been prepared within the intergalleries of Ce(IV) exchanged-montmorillonite clay by polymerizing aniline using Ce(IV) ions present within the intergallerie of the MMT. Also PANI/Na+-MMT has been prepared by polymerizing aniline incorporated to intergalleries using persulfate oxidant added to the dispersion of Na+-MMT. PANI intercalation within the interlayer of clay has been conferedby XRD, SEM, FTIR, and TGA studies. Thermogravimetric analysis results suggest that the cerium ion intercalated nanocomposite is thermally more stable than the pristine MMT nanocomposite and the PANI/Na+-MMT.
